def.para:
An orientation of an n-dimensional subspace V of \RNr[k] is given by a choice of an ordered basis \EuScript{B} = (\Vect{b}_1 , \dots , \Vect{b}_n ) of V.
orientationof a subspace of \RNr[k]
is given by the choice of an ordered n-tuple \EuScript{B} = (\Vect{b}_1, \dots , \Vect{b}_n) of V. – Definition of the concept.

section.body.para: In an arbitrary n-dimensional subspace V of \RNr[k] we do not have a canonical orientation. However, given two ordered bases of V, we have the means to decide whether they determine the same or opposite orientations of V.

def.caption: Same orientation
def.para: Two ordered bases \EuScript{B} = ( \Vect{b}_1 , \dots , \Vect{b}_n ) and \EuScript{C} = ( \Vect{c}_1 , \dots , \Vect{c}_n) of a subspace V of \RNr[k] determine the same orientation of V if the coordinate conversion matrix C_{\EuScript{B}\EuScript{C}} satisfies \det( C_{\EuScript{B} \EuScript{C}} ) > 0 . Else \EuScript{B} and \EuScript{C} are said to represent opposite orientations of V.
